awd_titl_txt: SNM: Manufacturing Autonomy for Directed Evolution of Materials (MADE-Materials) for Robust, Scalable Nanomanufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The development and manufacturing of cutting edge materials typically involves time-consuming materials and process design phases, followed by extensive testing of samples to adjust process conditions as the manufacturing scales up from the lab, to pilot plan, to industrial process scale. These distinct steps drive up the cost barrier to introduction of new and improved materials into the industrial pipeline and increase the cost of domestically manufactured advanced nanomaterials. Fortunately, recent developments in numerical modeling, additive manufacturing, and rapid testing of materials suggest that a new approach to material development and nanomanufacturing, where the previously distinct and time-consuming phases could be carried out nearly instantaneously to arrive at optimal material structure as well as process conditions for its manufacture. The focus of this award is to revamp the traditional, open-loop synthesis of nanostructured materials by: 1) using a versatile 3-D printing approach to manufacture these nanomaterials and nanostructures, 2) incorporate material property characterization directly into the printing process, and 3) use an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm to adjust on the fly process conditions to achieve desired material properties. These concepts and components will be integrated into technical coursework, hands-on research opportunities, and outreach workshops to a broad range of students and the public. The co-PIs plan to leverage existing outreach and educational activities through their group's collaboration with a local museum, as well as curricular and extracurricular activities.
 
The approach and framework is an investigation of process modeling, materials synthesis and characterization, and system design to autonomously discover new material configurations and reduce manufacturing defects and uncertainty. This AI framework will "understand" process-structure-property relationships, manufacturing constraints, and, importantly, statistical variations in material properties and manufacturing quality. The intellectual merit of this study is the discovery of general nanomanufacturing tools and feedstocks, with supervisory genetic algorithms, that autonomously correct for defects and compensate for innate manufacturing inaccuracies by a search for alternative designs; this is in contrast to standard tools that minimize uncertainty (e.g. environmental controls) or rely on post-fabrication characterization with human intervention. The framework will be tested using nanoscale additive manufacturing (AM) as the fundamental manufacturing tool and nanostructured metamaterials as the application. The paradigm and nanoscale metamaterials made via this approach have far-reaching impacts on scalable nanomanufacturing for integrated systems. The paradigm of systems that autonomously evolve parameters to meet construct specifications is extensible to macroscale additive manufacturing and pharmaceuticals where the process parameter space and chemistries available is vast, and design is not intuitive. Additive nanomanufacturing has the potential to transform metamaterial design by enabling design in 3-dimensions (3D) with multiple materials, creating complex composite metastructures.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The development and manufacturing of cutting edge materials typically involves time-consuming materials and process design phases, followed by extensive testing of samples to adjust process conditions as the manufacturing scales up from the lab, to a pilot plant, to an industrial scale process. These distinct, serial steps drive up the cost barrier to the introduction of new and improved materials into the industrial pipeline and increase the cost of domestically manufactured advanced nanomaterials. Fortunately, recent developments in numerical modeling, additive manufacturing, and rapid testing of materials suggest that a new approach to material development and nanomanufacturing, where the previously distinct, serial, and time-consuming phases could be carried out nearly simultaneously to arrive at optimal material structure as well as process conditions for its manufacture. The focus of this award is to study the concept of autonomous manufacturing for nanostructured materials by (Fig. 1): 1) using a versatile 3-D printing approach to manufacture these nanomaterials and nanostructures, 2) incorporate material property characterization directly into the printing process, and 3) use an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm to adjust on the fly construct designs and process parameters to achieve the desired material properties.

The broader impacts of this project is in the definition and demonstrations of autonomous manufacturing and in the study of nanoscale 3D printing of optical and infrared metamaterials. Many of the colors we see in the natural world are not the result of absorption by pigments, but because of some colors being reflected and refracted strongly due to structural arrangements of materials at the micro- and nano-scale. These arrangements, referred to as photonic crystals (PCs), allow us to design spectral response across virtually any wavelength of electromagnetic radiation, opening many new applications, from advanced biomedical imaging to high-speed fiber optic communications. Today, much of micro- and nano-fabrication uses “subtractive” manufacturing techniques, where material is removed to create a desired structure. These mature technologies are inherently wasteful. In contrast, this work focused on a “bottom-up” or additive approach to creating PCs, using micro- and nano-scale 3D printing and fiber drawing.

The intellectual merit of this proposal is driven by three complementary research aims. 

Our team developed a concept of autonomous manufacturing systems that can learn how to design and manufacture complex geometry artifacts that match user-defined properties. These systems employ a manufacturing cell that can automatically manufacture and then characterize and test an artifact, and a machine learning based cognition element that can autonomously change artifact design and process parameters (Fig. 2).  New ideas were developed to make the learning algorithms data efficient so that they can work with the high cost of data collection inherent in manufacturing. For example, we demonstrated that our systems can learn to fabricate 3D acoustic metamaterials, a type of complex geometry artifact, with desired spectral response using 10 times less data than traditional design approaches, and 1000 times less than established machine learning methods. The proposed manufacturing systems have the potential to accelerate the product design and manufacturing pipeline by a large margin using data efficient machine learning algorithms. 

Our team studied the autonomous quality control of micro/nano-scale (micrometer in-plane resolution and nanometer thickness resolution) 3D printing (Fig. 3). Material interactions at the microscale are investigated to derive better models of the spatial interactions within micro- and nano-scale 3D printing. Then, spatial iterative learning control (SILC) was used to regulate and automate material deposition at the microscale to improve the performance and reliability of 3D printing processes, without human operator intervention. The proposed SILC framework addresses the combined challenges of incorporating multiple dynamic models into the framework due to the interactions driven by the different build materials and different layers as a part is built layer-by-layer. SILC is augmented by a spatial model predictive control (MPC) in order to impose input constraints associated with the 3D printing processes and improve robustness and performance of the additive process. The feasibility of the proposed spatial control frameworks to direct the deposition process at the microscale are demonstrated through the experimental validations on an electrohydrodynamic jet (e-jet) printing process and simulation case studies.

We successfully printed all-polymer PC multilayers and arrays having structural color properties (Fig. 4). We also incorporated all-polymer PCs into fibers, which could allow for direct weaving or knitting of optical “barcodes” into apparel, enabling authentication and life cycle textile tracing and sorting for the circular economy. The 3D printing and fiber drawing techniques described in our publications also enabled convenient in-situ measurement of the manufactured article’s photonic properties, permitting on-the-fly adjustment of printing (and drawing) parameters through reinforcement learning algorithms.

Technical activities were complemented by a set of undergraduate research experiences, including the TEK-8 program at Ohio State where students translated their research experiences into educational modules for grade school students. 

 


Last Modified: 05/15/2023
Modified by: David J Hoelzle
